data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 3:56 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
It is 3:56 and we are beginning the deposition of Mayra Rodriguez
with the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States
So this is a deposition of Mayra Rodriguez conducted by the committee pursuant
At this time, I'd ask you, Ms. Rodriguez, to introduce yourself and spell your last
And, counsel, can you please introduce yourself?
B-1-a-k-e, and I'm the attorney for Ms. Rodriguez.
My name is Wright Blake, W-r-i-g-h-t, last name is Blake,
I am a senior investigative counsel to
I will be leading the deposition, but others may jump in with
And in the room with me are
he's staff for the select committee,
on the Webex are several members of the select committee staff, including
investigative counsel for the select committee.
So before we begin, I do just want to go over a few of the ground rules for
You are appearing pursuant to subpoena, and there is an official reporter who will
As you probably heard, this is also being recorded
on the Webex platform, but the official record of this deposition is the one that's being
There are two of them there.
There's only one who's taking the record at a time,
generally, and they may trade off.
you will be able to review, if you choose to, after the deposition is complete.
But there is going to be one continuous record which
Because the official record, though, is the reporter, they can't take things down
like nonverbal responses or shaking your head.
questions in words and not gestures.
So we just ask that you answer the
And also for ease of the reporter, if you let me finish my question before you
answer, then I'll also let you finish answering before my next question, and that should
make it a fairly easy process.
We do ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If you don't recall something, that's fine, you can say so.
not clear to you, please feel free to ask for clarification and I will do so.
And if I ask a question that's
If you do refuse to answer a question, you can only do so based on privileges
And if you do have an objection, then the staff, we
can either proceed with the deposition or seek a ruling of the chairman on the objection.
And if the chairman overrules any objection, you would be required to answer the
Do you understand everything we've gone over so far?
I do also want to remind mind you that it is unlawful to deliberately provide false
And since this deposition is under oath, doing so could expose
you to criminal penalties, including lying to Congress, under 18 U.S.C. 1001 for criminal
your right hand to be sworn in.
Then at this time I would ask that you stand and raise
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
And before we jump into the questions, just logistically, if you ever need a break
or you want to stop and speak with your attorney, please let us know and we can
to speak with your attorney to both turn off your camera and go on mute, and that way
we won't hear anything you guys discuss.
I think we've found in this process that it's usually easiest if you want
So the first thing to go over is you received a subpoena from the select
committee to produce documents and appear today.
And you are the Mayra Rodriguez who's listed in the subpoena
It's also shown up on the screen, if you're able to see that.
We did receive and I'm going to show exhibit 2, a letter from you
Is that the document that you provided to the select committee in response to the
So did you search for documents?
And did you look through text messages that you may have had to
look for documents responsive to the subpoena?
I would not have received a text.
So I did not look through my texts.
Not even a text about, like, planning or organizing or showing up at
I don't believe that I received a text.
Did you look in your email, for
example, for any documents that are responsive to the select committee's subpoena?
And it says, "I do not have any documents to
What about saved documents, hard copy documents, if you had any,
And as we go through this, I'll ask you certain planning or
text message that you can recall as we're going through this, I would just ask that you let
documents that you end up having.
And if you do think of anything, like you have an email or a
And then we can work with Mr. Blake to get any responsive
And I would ask, to the extent that you haven't already looked through your text
messages for any responsive documents, that you do so there as well.
So, Ms. Rodriguez, where do you live?
I live in the city of Grosse Pointe Farms, Michigan.
How long have you been in Michigan?
What do you do for a living?
What type of law do you practice?
I practice probate and child welfare.
Now, you were a Republican elector -- or a proposed Republican
Had you done that before in previous elections?
How did you become a proposed elector for the 2020 Presidential election?
At a 14th District meeting, I was selected by the members that were there.
District meeting of whom, which group?
So is it fair to say you're active in party politics in Michigan?
She was the chair of the party, so for 2 years I knew her.
Now, at the time, the Michigan GOP chair was Laura Cox.
Did you have personal interactions with her or was it really just a kind of a
It was just going to Republican events and I would see her there.
And we may get into some additional questions about her, but there are a
few others that I'll ask you about, including other people who acted as electors for the
She is our RNC person from Michigan.
And did you communicate with her about meeting as alternate electors for
When we went to the meeting, we -- that's when I talked -- well, not her in
And we'll get into the specifics about how the meeting came to be
But what about Meshawn Maddock, do you know her?
And did you interact with her during -- or, excuse me, before you met to
vote as alternate electors in the 2020 election?
So the Michigan election -- or the Presidential election in Michigan -- was
called on Wednesday, November the 4th, after the election, so the day after the election.
And President Biden was declared the winner, and he won by
Are you able to see exhibit No. 3 that's shown there on the screen?
If you could pull up exhibit No. 3, please.
And this is an amended certificate of ascertainment of the electors
of the President and Vice President of the United States of America.
Governor of Michigan, Governor Whitmer, where she essentially certifies that the people
listed there would be electors for the electoral college from the State of Michigan.
Are you familiar with this document?
You have to repeat your message.
Do you recall ever receiving a document like this with your name on it
Do you recall ever receiving this document from anybody?
designating you as an elector from the State of Michigan?
At this time, I'd like to invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
And is that because you think your answers might tend to
incriminate you in a proceeding, a later criminal proceeding?
When did you first hear talk about casting electoral votes for Donald
Trump, even if he did not win the State of Michigan?
I take my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
From whom did you first hear that the Republican electors would
meet to vote for then President Trump, despite the fact that he lost the State of
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Are you aware of any efforts to start planning for Republican electors to
meet in the State of Michigan even if President Trump lost and -- let me rephrase that.
Were you aware before the election on November 3rd that Republican electors
would meet to vote for President Trump even if he lost the State of Michigan?
I take my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent, please.
Did you ever communicate with Laura Cox about the Republican electors
meeting to cast electoral college votes for President Trump even though he lost the State
I take the Fifth Amendment to remain silent.
Did you ever communicate with anybody in the Trump campaign about
Republican electors meeting to vote and cast electoral college votes for President Trump,
despite him losing the popular vote in Michigan?
You did not communicate with anybody in the Trump campaign?
Do you know who Boris Epshteyn is?
No, I don't know that person.
Do you know the name Mike Roman?
Do you know the name Mike Brown?
I believe Mr. Flynn, I'd represent to you, that he may have been there when
you met and cast votes as Republican electors for President Trump, as a lawyer for the
campaign and election day operations coordinator.
Does that change your mind about whether you know Mr. Flynn?
I wasn't introduced to Mr. Flynn.
How about Christina Bobb, former news reporter, also working
He could have been there, but I was not
Did you ever talk to or see Mr. Rudy Giuliani in any dealings in
Michigan related to electoral college votes?
Do you know the name Jenna Ellis?
No, does not ring a bell.
Do you know somebody named Kenneth Chesebro, C-h-e-s-e-b-r-o?
about electoral college votes and alternate electors meeting to cast votes for President
Does that ring a bell as far as Mr. Chesebro in your mind?
Do you know Judge James Troupis?
How about John Eastman, do you know him?
I'd represent to you that Mr. Chesebro wrote several memoranda
And you never communicated with any of the people on the list we
When you first learned that you would be meeting to cast votes for
When you -- let me rephrase that.
When you first learned that you'd be meeting to cast electoral college votes for
then President Trump, despite the fact that he lost in Michigan, what were you told was
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Did you ever have any discussions with the alternate electors who didn't
actually show up to cast electoral college votes on December 14th?
Do you know who that is?
You're saying he was an elector.
That's what you're telling me, he was an
elector, so -- I don't know who that is.
Do you remember at the meeting on December 14th, before casting
votes, electoral college votes for then President Trump, do you remember having to
replace electors who didn't show up?
There were some people who did not show up.
Do you remember Gerald Wall being one of them?
I don't -- there were -- I think there were, like, two or three
So he could have been one.
I don't know him personally, though,
Did you ever learn why those people didn't show up?
Never provided a reason as to why they didn't come on December 14th to
What was the reason in your mind for casting an electoral college vote for
then President Trump on December 14th, despite the fact that he had lost the State of
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Did you talk to any alternate electors from other States?
to you that Pennsylvania, Georgia, Wisconsin, New Mexico, Nevada, and Arizona all had
separate slates of electors that cast votes for then President Trump.
No, I didn't speak with anyone from out of State.
Did you ever have a conference call with lawyers about casting votes,
electoral college votes, for President Trump?
When you showed up to the meeting on December 14th, did you have any
paperwork that you brought with you, namely electoral college vote certificates or
I assert my right to invoke my Fifth Amendment right.
Who organized the actual meeting place and time for the meeting of these
Do you know if it was Ms. Berden, Kathy Berden?
I understand that alternate electors were not allowed to bring their phones
It wasn't you, I take it.
I don't know who did that.
Was there somebody who was taking phones before you
went into the building where you met as alternate electors?
I left mine in my car.
So I don't know if there was someone taking the
phones if you didn't leave it in your car.
Do you remember who told you that?
It would have been a MIGOP staff member.
I want to say Tony Zammit.
Were you ever told why that was necessary to not bring phones in?
And where did you meet as alternate electors on December the 14th?
I invoke the Fifth Amendment, my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Do you remember if this person, Mr. Zammit, did he come with paperwork
But you were told to not to bring it in beforehand?
So I remember him being there.
that ultimately the alternate electors filled out and signed?
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Did you meet at the capitol building to cast electoral college votes for then
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Just to back up to one thing you mentioned.
I'm in a very different area from Lansing.
I believe you said you met at
Is that on Seymour Street in Lansing, to the best of your knowledge?
Now, the street, I think it's Seymour.
The capitol is in Lansing, so I
Were there restrictions on the people who were allowed into the
GOP headquarters to cast votes in the -- on December 14th?
I don't know what you mean by restrictions.
Like, was the public allowed to be there with you?
I went in there as elector, you know.
Do you remember -- and you were cut off at the end there -- but do you
remember anybody other than electors who were there meeting on December 14th at
Yes, there were other people there.
Don't know them by name, but Trump people were there.
And why do you say Trump people?
Because I was told that there's Trump people here, so --
And when you say Trump people, do you mean campaign people?
When I say Trump people, people who -- actually, that's probably a fair
Do you remember who any of them were?
Probably some of the names that you read off.
How many of those people associated with the Trump campaign were there?
I understand that Meshawn Maddock showed up with her husband Matt
Maddock, as well as lawyers from the Amistad Project and a camera crew.
I remember -- Meshawn Maddock was there.
was there, but I could be wrong.
And the Amistad Project, I don't even know what that
Do you remember a camera crew being there?
I remember when I walked into the MIGOP headquarters there was -- there
No, they were outside of the building.
I don't know if they ever came in.
Do you know if they were restricted from coming in in any way or you just
Were they allowed inside to witness and record the meeting of electors on
I just saw them when I came into the building, they were outside the
Were you interviewed at any point related to your role as an alternate
Did those camera crews that were there, did they ask you for an interview?
Now, a gentleman named Ian Northan was there and accompanied a group
I don't -- I did not interview.
to the capitol after the vote of the alternate electors on December 14th.
Do you remember Ian Northan being there?
I don't know who that is.
And we'll show you a video in just a little.
video and maybe you'll recognize him that way.
I understand that somebody who was associated with the Trump campaign, the
individual I identified before, Shawn Flynn, was there and spoke to the group about an
example of alternate electors meeting and casting votes from 1960 in Hawaii.
Do you remember somebody from the Trump campaign talking about the Hawaii
Do you remember what she said specifically?
Do you remember that State being Hawaii?
I understand that the electors convened in the basement of the GOP
I only remember Meshawn Maddock talking about that this had been done
So if someone else talked about it, I don't remember.
Just that alternate electors were done in another State.
I really don't remember which State she mentioned.
Yeah, it was the lowest floor.
Was there any reason in particular that the basement was selected for this,
I also understand that people were brought up a couple at a time to sign an
affidavit, essentially attesting to who you are.
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
On the screen is exhibit No. 6, and page one is titled "Memorandum."
written to the President of Senate, the Archivist of the United States, the secretary of

Kathy Berden, chairperson, electoral college of Michigan.

find duplicate originals of Michigan's electoral votes for President and Vice President, as

And if you can go to the next page.
Do you recognize this document, Ms. Rodriguez?

I won't read the whole thing, but I will read the first paragraph
"We, the undersigned, being the duly elected and qualified Electors for

And if you can go to the next page, please.
Do you recognize that document that we just looked at, page 2?
And then it lists a number of things it's certifying,
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
On page 3 it has a series of signatures that says, in sum and substance, that
on this 14th day of December the following people signed these documents.
second down from the left is Mayra Rodriguez, Secretary.
I take the Fifth Amendment to remain -- invoke my Fifth Amendment right to
And do you recognize this signature page?
I take the Fifth Amendment -- I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain
I understand that Ms. Maddock took pictures -- or at least one picture, I should
say -- from the meeting of the alternate electors on December the 14th.
Yes, I recall having a group picture taken.
Do you have a copy of that picture?
Why did you take a group picture?
Well, we were just told to let's take a picture, so we took a picture.
I don't remember who said it.
Did that occur before the electors met and filled out paperwork or after?
I invoke my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Did you ever get a copy of the paperwork that you filled out and signed as an
So after the electors met at the GOP headquarters in Michigan, I understand
that there was a walk or a march to the capitol in Lansing.
Were you -- did you go in that march to the capitol in Lansing?
Why didn't you go with them?
I didn't see a need to go.
Did you ever talk to anybody who did go and ask them about their
I don't recall talking to anybody afterwards.
If you can play exhibit No. 9, please.
This is a video of what happened at the capitol on December 14th.
the right with short brown hair and it looks like a blue scarf or bandana with white stars
We just paused exhibit No. 9, which is a video, at 1 minute and 54
You can see the back of two people's heads there.
Do you recognize who that is?
The first is the woman on
And that gentleman who is -- we're looking at the back of his hair as
He's wearing a blue mask and a tan overcoat it appears.
Do you remember either of those people being at the Michigan GOP
headquarters on December 14th while you were there?
You know, they could have been there.
I don't know what their names are.
If you can pull up exhibit No. 7.
And while we're doing that, at the point of December 14th, did you know that the
State of Michigan had certified now President Joseph Biden as the winner of the popular
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
At various points throughout the post-election period -- and to be clear, that
would be after November the 3rd -- there was reference to State legislatures meeting and
reviewing evidence of fraud in order to pick or ratify a separate set of electors.
Do you remember that, those discussions coming up in the State of Michigan after
There were a lot of discussions regarding the election.
particular which ones I remember over others, but it's been a long battle here.
And do you remember that coming up, and specifically for
the State legislature to meet and essentially choose the Republican slate of electors for
the State as opposed to the Biden set of electors?
I wasn't involved with any of that discussion, so I really can't say.
You don't have any personal knowledge of any of that?
I mean, I may have read something in the paper, but no personal
Did you contact any State legislators, either in the Michigan House or
Michigan Senate, about having them choose a slate of electors?
Now, I was chair of the 14th District and there may have
been something out of our district.
Is there something that's giving you that memory that maybe
Are you thinking of anything in particular?
was one in particular with this.
Well, I know that the group was very active with the election and the
So we were putting out a lot of resolutions, but I don't know if there
Now, this, exhibit 7, that you're looking at, it is a statement from
the date that the electoral college met, December 14th, and said essentially that then
President Biden was the winner and there's nothing that really anybody could do about
that in the State of Michigan.
And he issued a statement on -- either on or just before
And if you'd like to read it, I'd be happy to pause and let
Were you aware that Senator Shirkey came out and said that the legislature
effectively wasn't going to do anything to change the results of the election in Michigan?
It may have -- nothing was ever sent to me personally, but there was a lot of
So he may have said that.
And at that time do you remember Senator Shirkey indicating that
now President Biden had won and there's no reason to change it?
Again, I don't have any communication with this person.
I don't know what was out there at the time.
any -- I just don't recall that.
After the alternate electors -- and when I say that, I'm again
referring to the Republican electors who met and cast votes for Donald Trump on
December 14th -- after they met, did you ever talk to anybody who was involved in that,
any of the other people who met and cast votes that day?
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
And to be clear, the question was did you -- or was meant to be, I
should say, that may not have been all that clear, but meant to be -- did you ever talk to
anybody about what you did as an elector on December 14th, the meeting, the casting of
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
I'm going to go over several provisions of law.
I don't know if as a lawyer
State of Michigan are those -- who end up voting for President -- are those in the party
that receive the most Presidential votes.
But Michigan Code 168.42 says that the electors from the
And then 168.47 says that electors shall convene in the senate chamber at the
capitol of the State at 2 p.m., eastern standard time, on the first Monday after the second
Wednesday in December following the election.
And 1678.46 says a person's not an elector essentially until the Governor sends a
certificate to that person in triplicate bearing the seal of the State, notifying him or her of
So those three legal provisions, did any of those concern you before you met with
others at GOP headquarters on December 14th?
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
If we could pull up exhibit No. 6 again, page 2 specifically.
So subsection A there on page 2 of exhibit No. 6 says that the electors certify that
"we convened and organized in the State Capitol, in the City of Lansing, and at 2:00 p.m.
Eastern Standard Time on the 14th day of December, 2020, performed the duties
Did any of the electors, including yourself, who met on December 14th at the GOP
headquarters have concerns about signing a statement making such a certification?
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
If you can go down, please.
Bear with me just a moment, Ms. Rodriguez.
If you go to the top of the page, page 2, correct, top of the page, it says, "We, the
undersigned, being the duly elected and qualified Electors for President and Vice
President of the United States from the State of Michigan."
Did anybody, including yourself, who met in the GOP headquarters on December
14th express concerns about certifying that you or anybody else were the duly elected
At this point, I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
My understanding is that one of the reasons that alternate electors
met and cast votes in various States for President Trump, despite the fact that he had lost
those States, was because there was a possibility that any of the court cases would be
successful and there would be a need to have alternate electors essentially in place.
Are you aware of that justification for having alternate electors meet and cast
I don't know anything about those other States, and for the rest of it I take
And so with respect to Michigan you're taking the Fifth is what you're
But with Michigan, you're taking the Fifth.
With Michigan, I am asserting the Fifth.
I don't know anything about other States.
And are you aware that by December 14th in Michigan there had
been, I believe, at least six cases that had rejected challenges to the election by the time
of the electoral college meeting on December 14th, those being at least Constantino v.
City of Detroit, Trump v. Benson, Trump v. Benson in Federal court, Johnson v. Benson,
Stoddard v. Detroit, and King v. Whitmer?
Were you aware that at some level the courts had rejected electoral challenges in
I assert the Fifth Amendment, please.
Meshawn Maddock gave an interview, I believe to Crossroads, a reporter
associated has a YouTube channel and others, and during that -- we have the recording.
And we'll play that for you.
Do you recognize that voice as being Meshawn Maddock?
And in there she said the Trump campaign -- or, excuse me, I'll back up.
She said, "We fought to seat the electors.
The Trump campaign asked us to do that."
Do you agree that the Trump campaign asked the Republican Party or parts of the
Republican Party in Michigan, to seat the electors as Ms. Maddock said?
I assert my Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Somewhat separately, we understand that the President called somebody
named William Hartmann and Monica Palmer after the Wayne County certification in
Do you know anything about those calls to Mr. Hartmann or Ms. Palmer?
I believe that the President called Monica Palmer.
How do you know he called Ms. Palmer?
She said it to the group.
What did she say to the group?
That the President spoke to her.
Did she say anything about what happened on that call?
That's all I remember, that she got a call from the President.
She didn't explain what the President said?
Well, it was all around the time about the -- this was happening right after
perfect, is that the President called her.
So that's all she said, as I recall, my memory is not
But she didn't elaborate and say the President told me this, or asked
me this, or requested that we do this.
The only thing I remember is that the President called her.
And I understand that there is various levels of outreach to an
individual named Aaron Van Langevelde who's on the State Board of Canvassers before
the State met to certify the vote from Michigan.
Do you know anything about the outreach or pressure on Mr. Van Langevelde
I don't know anything about that.
Is there anything that you -- going back to the Monica Palmer call -- when
she told you and the group about that call, what do you remember her specifically
That the President had called her.
You know, that I remember for sure, is that the President called her.
Anything more just it would be speculation on my part and I don't want to do that.
do remember she said that the President called her.
Did she say if anybody else was involved in that call?
I think that Ronna may -- Ronna may -- Ronna may have
introduced the President to her on that call.
I'm just -- because I'm not positive, I'm not
Just on the memory of that situation, that's how I remember it.
Do you remember anything else, whether her specific words or not, that she
Is that based on your memory of how she -- how Ms. Palmer
said or conveyed to the group about when she was also -- when Ms. Palmer was also
talking about this call from the President?
I'll just take a moment here.
I don't know if you have any follow-up
questions to anything we've been over.
Just give us one moment, Ms ..
I think we're wrapping up here.
Have you talked to any of -- anybody else, other than your lawyer, Mr. Blake,
and I don't want to get into the substance of that -- but have you talked to anybody else
about your subpoena, your production of documents, or your appearance for deposition
I've spoken with Kathy Berden, just let her know that I had received
When you spoke to Ms. Berden, did you talk about how you would approach
And I've spoken with Meshawn Maddock to let her know that I received a
Everyone's been seeing it in the paper.
your production of documents or testimony to the select committee?
No, I did not speak with her regarding production of documents or my
I just told her I don't know why they're subpoenaing me.
We couldn't understand what value we would have to this
Did not speak with her regarding documents.
Then at this time, I think we've reached the end of the deposition.
you, Ms. Rodriguez and Mr. Blake, for showing up.
Sometimes this isn't always the easiest with virtual
But I appreciate you being here.
We are going to leave for purposes of procedure the deposition open at this time,
and I'll be in touch with you, Mr. Blake, about that.
But at this point we can go off the
[Whereupon, at 4:46 p.m., the deposition was recessed, subject to the call of the
I told her, as I told Kathy, I
And testimony, did not go over testimony at all.
Did you talk to her about how or whether to

I have read the foregoing _ _ pages, which contain the correct transcript of the
